properties.markdownProperty:
**Documents** and **Objects** are stored in the same directory (*objects*) following the same file structure and naming convention. The word 'element' will be use in order to explain both documents and objects file structure.
The XML file is name after the unique identifier for the element. It contains an *object* tag with the following attributes:
- 'id': Unique identifier of the element. - 'classes': Element classes. They are separated by space, the last class in the list is consider the main class of the element. - 'acceptedChildren': List of accepted children classes by the element. - 'acceptedParents': List of accepted parent classes by the element.
In the *object* tag there are three tags, *properties*, *children* and *traces*.
Inside *properties* each property type has its own tag. Every property has the following attributes:
- 'name': Name of the property. - 'category': Category of the property. - 'inmutable' (optional): If true, the property should not be edited by the user. - 'tooltip' (optional): Property tooltip - Special properties like enum or code may have more attributed or additional nested tags.
*Children* tag contains the children of the objects. There are a *child* tag that contains the *id* attribute for each child.
*Traces* tag contains the traces of the object. Each elements stores all the elements they are pointing to (targets). Each *traceProperty* tag inside *trace* define a possible type of trace the that elements implements. Each *traceProperty* has the following attributes:
- 'name': Name of the trace. - 'category': Category of the trace. - 'acceptedTargets': Element classes accepted as targets for the trace. - 'traceType': Type of the trace (author, information source, etc).
There is a *target* tag with the *id* and *traceType* attribute for each target inside *traceProperty* tag.
